segments.text: AWS solutions architect associates
certification prep question 20 of 65. So
an e-commerce company is preparing for a
major flash sale event and based on
previous years the security team expects
distributed denial of service attacks
targeting their infrastructure and SQL
ejection attempts against their web
application. So the company needs
protection at both the network layer
against volumetric attacks and the
application layer against malicious
requests. Now the application runs
behind an application load balancer with
Amazon cloud in front of it. So which
two solutions should the solutions
architect implement? So let's identify
the key hints. Number one, distributed
denial of service DOS attacks. Volutric
network layer protection is what we're
going to need. Two, SQL injection. So we
need some kind of application layer
filter basically to prevent that attack.
Number three, network and application
layer. So we need both covered. And then
four is that we need an application load
balancer with CloudCrunch because that's
really where the protection is going to
begin. So let's talk about the options.
Option one, let's configure security
groups on the EC2 instances to block
DDoS traffic patterns. Option two, let's
enable AWS Shield advance to protect
against DOS attacks with 24/7 support
and cost protection. Option three, let's
deploy AWS W with SQNL injection match
rules attached to CloudFront and the
application load balancer. And then
option four, let's configure network ACL
to inspect and block SQL injection
payloads. And then option five, let's
enable Amazon Guard Duty to
automatically block malicious requests
in real time. Drop your answer in the
comments. So the hint says DDoS plus SQL
ejection. So we need specific tools
reaching the different attack types. So
option one, security groups filter by IP
and port. They can't really detect DOS
patterns or inspect network traffic.
Option four, knackles work on layers
three and four, but they can't read
application payloads to detect SQL
injection. Option five, guard duty can
detect threats and alert you, but it
doesn't really block requests. It's
detective. It's not preventative. So the
correct answers are option two and
three. So AWS Shield Advance, which by
the way is purpose-built for DOS
protection at the network layer,
includes a 24/7 AWS DOS response team.
It also includes cost protection during
attacks. And the other option is the AWS
WFT with SQL injection rules. So a web
application firewall or WFT is going to
inspect the HTTP request at the layer 7
at application layer. It's going to have
managed rules that detect and block SQL
injection patterns automatically. So
here's the key takeaway. Shield stops
DDoS. W stops application attacks. They
work at different layers. You need both.

fullText: AWS solutions architect associates certification prep question 20 of 65. So an e-commerce company is preparing for a major flash sale event and based on previous years the security team expects distributed denial of service attacks targeting their infrastructure and SQL ejection attempts against their web application. So the company needs protection at both the network layer against volumetric attacks and the application layer against malicious requests. Now the application runs behind an application load balancer with Amazon cloud in front of it. So which two solutions should the solutions architect implement? So let's identify the key hints. Number one, distributed denial of service DOS attacks. Volutric network layer protection is what we're going to need. Two, SQL injection. So we need some kind of application layer filter basically to prevent that attack. Number three, network and application layer. So we need both covered. And then four is that we need an application load balancer with CloudCrunch because that's really where the protection is going to begin. So let's talk about the options. Option one, let's configure security groups on the EC2 instances to block DDoS traffic patterns. Option two, let's enable AWS Shield advance to protect against DOS attacks with 24/7 support and cost protection. Option three, let's deploy AWS W with SQNL injection match rules attached to CloudFront and the application load balancer. And then option four, let's configure network ACL to inspect and block SQL injection payloads. And then option five, let's enable Amazon Guard Duty to automatically block malicious requests in real time. Drop your answer in the comments. So the hint says DDoS plus SQL ejection. So we need specific tools reaching the different attack types. So option one, security groups filter by IP and port. They can't really detect DOS patterns or inspect network traffic. Option four, knackles work on layers three and four, but they can't read application payloads to detect SQL injection. Option five, guard duty can detect threats and alert you, but it doesn't really block requests. It's detective. It's not preventative. So the correct answers are option two and three. So AWS Shield Advance, which by the way is purpose-built for DOS protection at the network layer, includes a 24/7 AWS DOS response team. It also includes cost protection during attacks. And the other option is the AWS WFT with SQL injection rules. So a web application firewall or WFT is going to inspect the HTTP request at the layer 7 at application layer. It's going to have managed rules that detect and block SQL injection patterns automatically. So here's the key takeaway. Shield stops DDoS. W stops application attacks. They work at different layers. You need both.
